ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about the fundamentals of economics, which I had no previous exposure to or experience with. We started off with the basics of supply and demand -- which in and of itself was very helpful & interesting -- and then moved into more models of consumer / producer behavior and all the different things you could do to affect a market. I particularly liked the last part of the class when we discussed Game Theory.
Learned so much about Microeconomics, as well as note-taking and study habits.
I learned basic economic principles. It was neat to be able to apply these concepts in other concepts and just in daily life!
Basics of microeconomics
I feel I have a solid understanding of introductory microeconomics.
The basics of market structure: in perfect competition, monopoly and oligopoly. Market failures such as market power and externalities. What happens after imposing a tax.
Basic microeconomics- Supply and demand, market structures, pareto efficiency, game theory, consumer and producer theory
This course built the groundwork for developing economic intuition and provided a connection between simple models to real-world problems.
This class was awesome! I feel that I learned the basics of microeconomics and this class has made me want to take future economics courses.

I learned to grapple with material that I did not understand when it was presented the first time since the lecture environment made us ingest an enormous amount of knowledge rapidly. I learned to work independently and reach out appropriately to instructors if the challenge became overwhelming.
I learned the basics of economics.
I learned much about introductory microeconomics.
I learned a lot about microeconomics as it was my first ever economics course. I learned how to think critically about how firms and consumers make their decisions and it was very insightful overall.
I developed a lot of insights into why the various concepts we considered worked in real life.
Very little learned.  No skills developed.
General microeconomic principles, reasoning
I learned a lot about market structures, consumer and producer theory, and how to be a better consumer of economics as a whole.
Basic foundational understanding of economics.
I learned microeconomic concepts which were interesting and relevant to the real world.
I got a pretty basic level of microeconomics. Nothing too complicated but did put words to things that we see in our economy.
How to think like an economist.
Basic economic information.

I feel like I have a solid foundation to understand the economic mechanisms of American society. I now feel like I can examine society not only from a cultural/social lens but also from an economic lens, especially in order to dissect the ways in which economics interact with different facets of society.

I learned the concepts that the class says it will teach (at least at an introductory level): supply, demand, consumer theory, producer theory, social welfare functions, taxation, monopoly, oligopoly, intro to Game Theory, and other intro micro staples. Beyond the material, I also learned how to learn in a big lecture environment. I think my note-taking skills improved dramatically. I learned how to study from my notes and reviewing lecture slides. I learned how to use problem sets and section to my advantage, and work with classmates. Just a great class, especially for incoming first-years who haven't taken a big lecture before.

This course was an incredible introduction to microeconomics with an emphasis on thinking in an economic framework. The class covers a wide range of topics in consumer and producer theory, markets/market structures, risk/uncertainty, and more. This course really changes how you look at the world in a very insightful way.

Great into econ course! We went over the perfect competition, monopolies, monopsonies, duopolies, consumer theory, producer theory, and a tiny bit of game theory-- everything you would want to familiarize yourself with.

An introduction to basic macroeconomics, so supply, demand, taxes, producer theory, consumer theory, perfect competition, monopolies, monopsonies, basic game theory, oligopolies, externalities. I got an insight into what economics as a discipline focuses on and some of the major questions it focuses on such as inequalities, market failures, redistribution and utility.
I learned about consumer and producer theory, different types of markets, and how certain actions affect those markets.
Producer theory, Consumer theory, how monopoly and monopsony work, Cornout duopoly, game theory, and social welfare functions.
I learned basic introductory economic skills through this course.
I learned the concepts of microeconomics and - generally - how they have applied to the real world. I've also learned how to take a large lecture course and  take a quantitative class.
I improved my economic intuition and learned about concepts relevant to everyday life.
Learned about basics economics and demand/supply graph, different economic models like monopolies, monopsonies etc.

I gained a solid understanding of foundational microeconomics topics and skills, as well as a small preview into the world of economics research and economic policy. I feel equipped to continue on to intro macroeconomics as well as intermediate microeconomics.
I learned about producer and consumer theory, game theory, and different form types.
microeconomics and how it works
Basic micro knowledge. Reasonable study habits and general advice.
I learned a lot of basic economics concepts and how to apply them to situations where they're relevant.
I learnt the key models with which we study the different markets around us. I learnt skills like how to find optimum quantities and price in the demand and supply model.
I learned a lot about the behind the scenes of economics that I knew very little about. I feel like I am a more well rounded student for having taken this course.
The course equips the students with an understanding of basic economic principles. Above all, it seeks to help students develop an economist-like rationale.
Basics of microeconomics; supply/demand/equilibrium, consumer theory, producer theory, basics of monopolies, etc.
I learned valuable introductory economics knowledge
Began to develop a better understanding of the foundations of economics and market structure

I knew absolutely nothing about economics before this, and feel like I learned a ton of the basic concepts through this course. We learned about supply, demand, perfectly competitive markets, monopoly, oligopoly, monopsony, social welfare functions, and lots more. I feel like I have a really good foundation to work from. I also learned so much about how to learn in a big college lecture course through this class. I got a lot better at note-taking, time management, finding a study group, studying, and pacing work.
I did not know about economics before this course, but it gave me a good insight into what I want to major in.
I learned more about how the economy works, and how everything has a reaction.
I learned the basics of microeconomics, as well as how to best think like an economist

Knowledge: producer/consumer theory, market structure/oligopoly, basic idea behind welfare theorems, game theory
Skills: interpreting graphs, connecting math to graphs to qualitative explanations
microeconomics.
This class was a great introduction to the world of economics. I gained many skills and really learned how to think like an economist.
I learned about the individual choices of economic agents.
All the nitty-gritty microeconomic terms, formulas, and techniques: consumer theory, producer theory, marginal analysis, markets, monopoly, monopsony, equilibrium, taxation, elasticity, profits, etc.
An understanding of microeconomics
A wide breadth of introductory economics concepts were covered.
I learned the basics of microeconomics: supply and demand, taxation, perfectly competitive markets, monopolies, etc...
I gained an introductory level knowledge of microeconomics.
I learned about how producers and consumers interact in a market and how they make choices and decisions in order to maximize profit / minimize costs.
I learned about economics and self studying habits.
Improved quantitative reasoning skills, increased interest in economics, learned how to learn in a large lecture setting
The usual microeconomics: supply, demand, marginal revenue, minimum wage, profits, and monopoly

I think the best thing the course teach you is different ways of looking at the world, including the idea of models and marginal analysis. They are part your tool kit to solve real-world problems you encounter beyond econ.
I learned a lot of Econ info and learned how to be in a big lecture class
I learned a lot about the functioning of our economic system.
Learned how to deal with supply and demand
I learned about the fundamentals of econ. Very good introductory class.
Lots of content about economics, as well as how to approach large lecture style classes.
very good class and interesting
I gained a vast amount of knowledge when it comes to the basics of economics. I also improved my studying skills while preparing for midterms and final exams.

This course gave my a strong understanding of the basics of microeconomics. The many, many graphs one must learn to draw for this class and how to manipulate them given a particular situation is certainly a skill I will take from this course. The course was also a review of basic algebra.

I think it's fair to say that this course helped me understand how complex the decisions of firms and consumers are and the numeric and contextual information that conditions their decisions. This course gave me an insight into many of the current events involving microeconomics that are written about in the news and highlighted in our lectures.
I learned the basics of supply and demand, optimal cost vs production, perfect competition, monopoly, game theory, oligopoly, social welfare, etc...
I learned A LOT more than I thought I would about microeconomics. I developed the necessary economic thinking that is essential for all economic courses, which is very important.
I learned how to think quantitatively and was introduced to problem sets.

I developed a strong base for microeconomics. I had taken AP micro, so much of the material was review. However, there were new ideas and material that I had not learned previously. It was difficult at times because the problems, equations, or definitions would not really answer problems or would obviously be excluding parts of the situation, which makes it harder to understand the concept if you really break it down, but I think that is the nature of an intro course.
An understanding of fundamental economics concepts and an application of these concepts to different markets in the world today.
I learned a lot of economics terminology that I had heard before but didn't really understand. It's made me more knowledgeable about how to distill real-life situations into models and patterns.
I learned the basics of economics.
I learned about microeconomic theory
I feel like I have been "thinking like an economist" on so many aspects of life and society after taking this class. Everything has economics!
Intuitive understanding of some of the forces driving markets and producer behavior.
Learned about microeconomics and firms supply/demand - intro to economics.
I gained a basic understanding of microeconomics and many critical thinking skills.
I hadn't had an econ course before so I learned a lot in this class. I learned about demand, supply, the consumer's problem, taxes, monopoly, monopsony, and externalities.
I learned about supply, demand, market competition, taxes, graphing, real-world applications, and more in this course.
This class, of course, taught me introductory microeconomics, but it also taught me how to approach difficult exams, how to interpret slopes, and how to integrate math with conceptual problems.
Basics of microeconomics, including rules of supply and demand, consumer and producer theory, etc.

I learned the basic foundations of microeconomics. Thank god I didn't skip this course (having took AP micro in high school), because the AP class I took did basically nothing to prepare me. This course was much more in depth and theoretical.
This class introduced me to the field of economics. We learned about supply and demand, taxes, market power, producer theory, and externalities.
I started this term with close to zero knowledge about economics, so I learned A LOT this term; whether it be about basic supply and demand curves or collusion between two firms.
This was my first econ class so I definitely learned a lot. How to apply math to econ, draw graphs and models, think like a economist, etc. Psets really made me think conceptually about problems.
Basic intro to economics
Basic knowledge of microeconomics.
A stronger understanding of microeconomic principles; a framework to analyze the decisions of individuals, firms, and governments
The development of skills to analyse world markets.
I learned a ton about microeconomics: supply and demand, monopoly, externalities, etc.
Supply and demand, producer and consumer theory, game theory, and welfare functions
I gained a strong foundation in microeconomics and analyzing how firms and markets function.
I developed a strong elementary understanding of micro. I understand a wide range of topics.
Built upon my basic economics understanding
Critical thinking, fundamental microeconomics skills, quantitative skill
I was able to learn more about consumer and producer theory
I learned a great introduction to Microeconomics, specifically a very analytical introduction.
Through this class I learned how to look at the world through an economic viewpoint and the basics of economics.
I learned the basic micro economic concepts like supply demand and different market types
I learned introductory economics in a clear and engaging way.
I learned how to analyze graphs with equations.
Learnt a lot of new economics
I learned to study!
Learned how to think like an economics

I learned lots of relevant theories that help me analyze the world both from an economic standpoint and an everyday-life standpoint. Outside of an economic context, you are introduced to lots of theories that help you think about how to make smart decisions.
How to understand markets and think like an economist.
I learned about economics in the real world and how to manipulate marketing strategies in order to maximize profit.
I learned the basics of microeconomics and microeconomic theory.
I had never taken an econ course before coming to Yale so I think that econ 115 was a great course that introduced us a to lot of different topics and showed what the possibilities were.
good introduction to economics
Great into to Econ
The basic of microeconomics

I think I have begun to develop an economic intuition through this course. I really appreciated the challenge of the questions that forced me to not only  internalize the material, but also use it creatively. I also appreciated the multiple ways in which information was presented, both in algebriac form and as intuitive explanation.
I developed a more analytical way to look at math instead of purely mathematics. It was the first time I ever took a course that utilized applied math.

This course was a great introduction for someone like me who has never taken an economics class before. Professor O'Dea, Dr. Morar, and the teaching fellows were amazing! While microeconomics seemed a little daunting, especially with its Quantitative Reasoning course credit, I was very happy with the quality of teaching and support I received throughout the term. If you are considering if economics is right for you, this course is definitely a good choice to see what you're getting yourself into.
Learned the principles of microeconomicssupply and demand, producer theory, consumer theory, and market structures.
I learned about how markets work, supply and demand, market power, and different types of taxes.

Prof. ODea allowed us to have a very thorough understanding of introductory microeconomics. I appreciated his use of real-world examples, and warnings against Econ 101isms. I feel prepared to move on to further economics.
General understanding of microeconomic principles (supply, demand, how outside factors/personal preferences influence market trends), how to display these trends graphically.

I am now able to understand microeconomic concepts when I read them in articles, which I think is really cool. I feel like my knowledge of how the world works is greatly improved because of this course. Some specific items are supply and demand, equilibrium, consumer and producer choices, and game theory. This class was extremely informative on all of these fronts, more so than I anticipated.
Problem solving, creating graphs.
Through this course, I gained a thorough knowledge of basic microeconomic concepts and their applications, as well as a base from which to branch out in other economics courses.
Good introduction to economics, learning about real life examples as well as the basic concepts
A basic foundation in microeconomics and insight into its connections with daily life.
Quantitative reasoning skills applied to real world economic problems, economic intuition
Taught us to think about the world in a different lens through econ. Was a good intro for starting to think about economics.

This course teaches basic economic intuition as well as terms, graphs, and concepts important to the study of economics. We also learned a lot about applications of different concepts we were learning since O'dea liked to connect lectures to real economics research or paper.
Intro microecon, how to learn in a lecture setting

I gained a solid introductory insight into microeconomicsit was fascinating to learn more about how markets work, why they're structured as they are, some of the benefits/trade-offs firms and consumers make, and principles surrounding markets as a whole. I feel like it made me a more knowledgeable consumer and member of society. I feel like I began to develop and hone a sense of economic intuition, especially as I began to see some of the content covered in class showing up, in ways, in the news or in my own interactions with markets as a consumer.
I learned a lot about the economy throughout this course. I also developed many strategies for studying and learning in a large lecture-style class.
Basic microeconomics
Although I struggled with mathematic concepts of the course, I developed a stronger economic intuition.
The ability to take notes and learn in the lecture format, intro microeconomics, how to complete problem sets- balancing work on my own and with others
I learned a lot about Microeconomic concepts, but more than anything I think the value of this course is sharpening basic math skills. It helped me get really quick at algebra in my math course.
This course focuses effectively on economic intuition, and helped me gain a basic familiarity with the subject.
I learned how to apply various Microeconomics principles in real life situations.
Microeconomic theories.
Knowledge on how producers and consumers operate and think.
Economics
Strong foundation in microeconomics.
I learned basic economic principles and sharpened my economic intuition.
Econ concepts
I learned about economics and its applications, and started discovering how it can help study so many aspects of our world and be helpful for many different fields
Learned the basic concepts of microeconomics and learned the skills to derive some of the fundamental laws of economics.
Graphing, critical thinking, the ability to extrapolate from what i have studied to answer challenging questions on exams.
This is a great background for microeconomics, as I learned about the forces that influence a market economy and different normative evaluations.

I built on the skills that I had learned in AP Microeconomics and was able to start linking basic economic principles to real world examples using my "economic intuition". New concepts included budget constraints and indifference curves, isoquant/isocost curves, pareto efficiency, social welfare functions, and the majority of applied math we used to calculate specific numbers. Though I received a 5 on the AP exam, approximately half of this course was completely new material, and for theory that I had already learned, this course required me to apply the theory where my AP class did not.
Good sense of intro microeconomics
How to manage my study time and navigate a big lecture class.
intro micro
I developed basic skills in microeconomics, and a basic understanding of producer and consumer theory.
A deeper understanding of economics and how it influences the world around us.

I acquired many new economic insights and learned how to use them to understand the world. The class not only taught me economic theories and principles, but also gave me the economic intuition to apply and make use of them.

Basics in Microeconomics: changes in market equilibriums, marginal etc., basics in setting up how a business might operate with regards to their situation(monopoly, perfectly competitive market) and strategies for evaluation.
basics of macroeconomics, market structures, economic theory

I deepened my understanding of how a market works, different markets that occur in the world, and how firms maximize their profits. I also gained insight into how to learn best in a big lecture setting.
A lot of interesting material presented.
Quantitative reasoning, approaching the basics of economics
I learned a lot about the ways in which markets work and the different types of markets. Also how the government is able to use taxes to stimulate markets
A great base skill set in economics that allowed me to apply it to the world.
Intro to economics and deeper into micro.
Foundations of microeconomics
I gained a knowledge of fundamentals microeconomic theory, and how individual cos Jemez and firms operate across different kinds of markets. I also learned other fundamental concepts of economics.
Learned the fundamentals of econ.
The basics of microecon

I developed lots of useful study skills by using the textbook, review sessions, forming study groups, and organizing my notes into flash cards to study. I also gained lots of knowledge around obviously our economy and how it really all works.
A good understanding of markets
I learned how to accurately learn about supply, demand, profit optimization, and so much more. i came away with a rea, understanding of how resources can be allocated.
Microeconomics, how to take notes efficiently
You get a good overview of basic economic principles and how to think about the world like an economist.
A broad overview of basic microeconomic skills on top of a surface-level understanding of current debates and research in the field, including but not limited to minimum wages, patents, and welfare.
Learning in a large lecture, using collaboration to to enhance understanding of the material.
Basic concepts in microeconomics: supply and demand, producer theory, consumer theory, elasticity, utility, monopoly, oligopoly and game theory, social welfare, externalities.

This course taught me basic principles of microeconomics. It also instilled specific skills related to managing a class with a very consistent workload, and helped me develop a sense for when I could figure something out on my own and when I needed to ask for help (e.g. through office hours).

I learned to think in an economic way by evaluating risk and comparing it to benefits. It helped my understanding in global economics (important for future financial decisions and an understanding of the world economy). Large forces that were previously just random words to me like price and demand actually made sense.
Microeconomics knowledge, synthesizing information, applying learned concepts to real world situations.
Got a strong foundation in understanding how economists think and some basic tools for understanding market behavior.

We learned about microeconomic theory and principles, diving into supply and demand, firms, labor/wages, etc.. We also learned about mathematical modeling and understood many economic concepts through equations and/or visual graph techniques.
I learned foundational microeconomic concepts like how firms behave under different market structures and how individuals and firms choose between goods and inputs.
This course presents and introduction to microeconomics and the skills necessary to succeed in a lecture setting

ECON 115 provides a detailed introduction to the analytical and algebraic methods of microeconomics. In particular, the course emphasizes the relationship between these two approaches, and in doing so, provides students with a solid intuition that can then be applied to a variety of economic problems.
Basic microecon knowledge
Making economic connections and using logic to explain consumer and producer choices
understanding of market structure

-This was my first ever economics course. Thus, I learned everything from supply and demand to game theory. 
-Independent studying
I gained a solid foundation in microeconomic theory.
I learned a lot about the basics of supply and demand and how changes in the market affect changes to production and consumption.
I learned a lot about basic microeconomics and how to apply the concepts.
I learned more about economics and how to critically analyze real life situations.
Basic Introductory microeconomics skills, how to write notes in a lecture
I developed a greater familiarity with a disciplined way of thinking about the world.
Micro economical knowledgd
Learned about markets, supply and demand, and how government policy can accommodate externalities and undesirable market outcomes.
how to think in a new way pertinent to economics (thinking more analytically, interpreting a concept in multiple ways)

Nothing out of the ordinary - time management in terms of reviewing a lot of material for exams, techniques in applying lecture concepts to mathematical problems, and in the case of the more recent papers applying multiple concepts simultaneously to solve more tricky tasks. In ECON 115 specifically, the large lecture format was definitely daunting, but taught me how to learn independently and in small groups, how to engage with discussion sections to reinforce or learn concepts missed during the lecture, and overall, how to get the most out of a class where engagement is honestly much more difficult compared to a small seminar class.
I developed a basic logical and algebraic understanding of microeconomic principles and the impact of governments on multiple types of markets
Introductory microeconomics concepts, analytical skills, reasoning skills

Skills: time management, note taking, thinking logically and critically, commercial and cultural awareness, data analysis 
Knowledge and insight: how decisions are made based on allocation of scarce resources, consumer & producer theory, welfare theorems, basic principles of economics

I gained a useful introduction to microeconomics, and I think the field of economics more generally. We were taught to look at the world from the perspective of trades and markets, and I really appreciated being introduced to a different way of thinking.
Developed and refreshed elementary algebraic skills and practiced applying this knowledge to unseen problems.
Going into it, I knew basic terms and broad concepts about economics but it was very valuable to learn very concrete knowledge from the course.
Better at economics, but also mathematical and logical thinking, which is the even better long-term benefit of taking this class.
Supply & demand, consumer & producer theory, market power, optimization, etc
I developed a great foundation in microeconomics.
This is a great introductory course into Economics and a great start towards exploring more Economics courses!

I learned a significant amount about how markets and capitalism functions. I felt that I was able to apply many of the insights from the course (for example utility, diminishing returns, etc.) to my life, and I definitely saw an interplay between much of what we leaned and the way I make decisions. I feel that the information I learned will be very useful to me as I navigate my personal finances and the world.
great understanding of basic Econ and how the economy works regarding supply and demand in different market structures
I gained a solid foundation in microeconomics, supplemented by some additional insights into economics research and applications.
basic microecon knowledge

I learned about what economics is and what economists study. Additionally I learned about market structures, individual firms, how to analyze economics questions both graphically and algebraically, market power, competition, introductory topics in game theory, and the problems/issues/questions modern economists are currently researching/thinking about.
I feel like I have a very good foundational understanding of microeconomics. I got a nice survey of what microeconomics really is and it helped me understand the benefits and cons of the Econ major.

I learned the basics of supply and demand, the differing elasticities of certain goods, the impact of government intervention, marginal analysis, and the pricing behaviors and cost structures of different types of markets.
good theory of econ
I learned the basics of microeconomics: concepts, graphs, problems, and some real-life applications.

I learned about supply, demand, equilibrium, taxation, consumer and producer theory, externalities, and other microeconomics topics. I learned how to use algebra and graphs to represent economic ideas. I also improved my ability to analyze data.
I developed basic micro-economics ideas and learned how to show them with graphs, math, or writing.
I developed important insights into both the significance and the limitations of markets as well as the fundamental principals of microeconomics.

I learned much about how society and economics work together, as well as details about microeconomics. Small things like how taxes affect supply and demand, and things like optimization of prices as well.
I learned much of the basics of microeconomics and economic reasoning.
Overall logic and reasoning skills

This course will teach you exactly what it says it will on the syllabus/if you read the textbook  the principles of basic microeconomics. But beyond the specific material, I feel like I also gained valuable economic intuition about how and why a market might react to a change.
Introductory microeconomics terminology and concepts
I developed both a basic and more advanced understanding of economics as well as an interest to further my study of economics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A strength was some of the great TAs and peer tutors. Specifically, I had Rodrigo for my section and found his teaching style very engaging and helpful. I also benefitted from Aidan Lee's peer tutoring hours to go over problem sets. I also liked the way that work was managed / assigned, with manageable psets and readings each week. I think a weakness was the slightly unbalanced distribution of course difficulty. I found the first midterm very straightforward, but the second midterm was very hard for me. I think we could have used some more help / instruction to get from the first exam to the second.
Using only elementary math seems like a nice concept in theory but it ends up overcomplicating some of the concepts and makes the course more difficult.
Taught very well, hard content though.

This course is extremely well-organized, and Cormac is a very talented lecturer. I found that lectures often went too slowly and were quite repetitive. However, it was a pretty low-stress and enjoyable class.

Strengths: Well-organized, helpful sections, helpful psets

Weankesses: Large, overcrowded lectures made it more pleasant to do the class virtually than in person. Also, although individual concepts were well-explained, I never felt like I understood why we were learning each concept, and how it fit into the bigger picture; I feel like I have come away with a piecewise understanding of the microeconomics, not a good, comprehensive foundation in the subject

Prof Cormac is an amazing lecturer and this is a must-take course especially when it's recorded. The only real downside was that all of the TF's were foreign exchange students with thick accents and it was often hard to understand them during section/ office hrs

Strenghts: Cormac O'Dean is such an amazing professor who made the lectures interesting and he is funny too. I absolutely loved having him as my professor.
Weaknesses: In a large lecture setting the learning experience is a lot more on students responsibility. It might be hard to focus or be brave enough to ask questions.

The course is organized very well especially considering it is such a large class. The main weakness from my point of view is the discussion sections. I attended sections taught by four different TFs, and the only section I found helpful was the one taught by the course director Dr. Morar. My regular section leader was an ineffective teacher and we never completed all of the assigned problems. I think it would be helpful for the course director and professor to sit in on some of the discussion sections and provide more feedback to the TFs.
This course is perfect if you are able to learn in a large lecture. There are plenty of ways to learn outside of class as well (office hours, section, etc.) if you need some extra help.

The discussion sections were a very useful part of the course, especially with Dr. Morar who cared deeply about what her students were learning. She made extra videos on the side to complement our learning which was incredible to see. The availability of peer tutor office hours was also greatly appreciated because it felt like we could almost always turn on our laptop and jump into an OH session when having difficulty with a problem set.
The course could be improved by making use of the textbook more often. There are certainly some great problems at the end of the textbook chapters which were almost never referenced or included in optional problem sets so the purchase felt wasteful.
One strength is that there are a lot of resources available for students. I can honestly say that I am not able to think of any weaknesses.

Strengths: good lectures, solid material, fun class

Weaknesses: hard to tell what will be tested and what will do
Strengths of this course: Cormac was a great lecturer and answered many questions. Lectures were also recorded which helped a lot. No weaknesses.

I think the section teachers were very hit or miss and didn't help much. Having better section teachers would have helped. Cormac O'dea was amazing. I also loved how lectures were posted online because I could go back and watch them later as review. This was a huge help and wish other courses offered this.

This course was executed relatively well for such a large lecture.  After talking to my peers in the smaller Econ 110 section I realized that would have been a better fit for me.  Personally, the content of the lecture seemed very detached from textbook and problem sets.  The lectures were not necessary nor were they beneficial to my knowledge. I found myself learning more from textbook readings and my peers.
Strengths: pretty easy content. Weaknesses: TF's not the best, math will confuse you a little because they don't go over it even though it is like 6th grade math.
Good course

I appreciate how lectures were recorded, especially in covid times, I felt that I could watch the lectures if I didn't feel comfortable. I thought the material was presented well in lectures, and psets really helped me solidify my understanding
The material was very interesting and it was taught well!

Prof. O'Dea was a strength and I think the workload was fair in the class too. I think the biggest weakness is how easy it is to get disconnected from the class but I don't know how that's solved with a class so large.  Another weakness was that section was never particuarly helpful in my opinion and if it was that could make the class easier to connect with.
Professor was very caring of the students.
I really enjoyed the large lectures and felt like I learned a lot in each one; discussion sections were also super helpful to review the new material.

I liked the structure of the course. There were ample materials for review and aid, which I really appreciated. I also enjoyed getting consistent grades through weekly problem sets, as it kept me on track in terms of reviewing course content. A weakness is that the lecture style was not always very engaging for me, but this is also due to the fact that the class was so large.

The strengths: Cormac O'Dea is great. I mention it later, but just putting it here. He makes the course pretty fun. It's such a big class, especially among first-years that it's more or less a social event, which is pretty hilarious and fun. The coursework is stimulating but not too challenging.

Weaknesses: I don't know. I don't really have many complaints. Great class. I loved it. Tests were pretty hard. They were curved, but still a little disheartening to feel prepared and just get wrecked a little bit.

The amount of support in the course is incredible, from the peer tutors, to the TFs, to the course director, and the professor. The class is incredibly interesting and very highly engaging, if you are interested in truly understanding the material. The lectures were incredible and sections were very helpful.

Strengths: Cormac is a great lecturer, lectures are recorded which makes it easier to understand some of the harder topics because you can go back, depending on the TF section was also extremely helpful
I thought this was a very well taught and crafted course. I didn't love the course material, and thus found it a bit difficult to remain engaged, but I don't think that was a fault of the course!

Strengths: Cormac is a super engaging professor and a great intro to econ and lecture style classes. The lectures were something I always looked to. Definitely a class worth taking in my humble opinion.
Weaknesses: Sections were sometimes less productive.

The course was well-organized, review sessions were very helpful, and the material itself was pretty straightforward. The only downside was that it was a huge lecture, making it a little difficult to focus.

Strengths: Problem sets every week to check in how well we understand the concepts taught in class.

Weakness: huge lecture class, so it is hard to ask questions and stay engaged
I think it is hard to understand the material in the lecture. Sections were not as helpful as I was hoping for. I often was missing the basic concepts that were brushed over to start a problem.
It's a large lecture, which can cause disturbances at times. Cormac handles this extremely well, and it just comes to show how greatly this course is taught and organized.

The strengths are in the lectures. I think Dr. O'Dea did a fantastic job explaining and contextualizing the content of the course. My only problem with the course was not knowing what the curve is or where I lied in the class. I think knowing your grade throughout the course would help.
I would appreciate more practice, especially with difficult conceptual problems.
The sections werent as helpful as they could have been since the class was so hard and confusing the instructors sometimes explained in the same way as cormac instead of a different approach.

Prof. O'Dea's lectures were very well-organized and well-organized, and he worked through lots of examples for every topic, which was incredibly helpful. Problem sets were an appropriate length and difficulty, and we were given an enormous number of resources to help us prepare for the exams. I'd say the only weakness was the sections: while I had a great TF, I heard really bad things about most of the TFs being really unhelpful and explaining things.
very hard to understand information and discussions sections were not helpful
I  think the course was well taught. I preferred watching the lectures at 2x speed but yeah, well taught. I felt the exams were well made and tested my knowledge well.
Strengths: Cormac O'Dea is a super engaging lecturer. Weaknesses: none.
good explanation of the content in lectures however sections moved a bit slow and didnt cover all of the content
The class was well taught and well structured. It could have been more engaging, but with basic concepts and such a big class size there's probably not much that can be done.
The strengths are the layout of the course and how it logically flows from topic to topic. However, I felt the sections were quite confusing and often, the work is rushed through.

The strengths were that they could be watched online, where you can control the speed of the lecture and also stop to take notes. Weaknesses were that because it is such a huge class, there is minimum individual attention even in sections.

The course was well taught and lectures were engaging and clear. I think discussion sections were often not very helpful and the practice problems we did were not always helpful in furthering my understanding of the material.

Professor O'Dea is a very clear and engaging lecturer. It was clear that he cared about the quality of his teaching and often grounded lecture topics in current, real-world examples. I can't think of any suggestions to improve this course.
Very strong teaching and allows time for questions, also improved course based on midterm evaluations
I think sections could be improved.

This is a really great introductory course, accessible to students with no economics background and needing no high-level math. A strength of the course is Professor O'Dea. His entire course was incredibly organized, well thought out, and engineered to help students learn. There were tons of available resources to help learning and he made lectures super engaging. It would have been really easy for this to be a boring course in a big lecture hall, but it wasn't. One small weakness is just that it was hard to get through all the material covered in class during section, so. if you needed help, you had to tackle asking for it on your own.
There are a lot of people, and that can be either a strength or a weakness for some. It was easy to get lecture material and the problem sets were not too difficult.
Sometimes it was hard to keep fully engaged in the lectures because the material was not as interesting.

Strengths- For a lecture format, the course is as engaging as can be
Weaknesses- Tests could probably benefit from being more cumulative, because the result is that by the end of the semester I could hardly remember what we learned in the beginning of the year.

Strengths: very well organized, great textbook, very clear and concise lecturer, very cool content
Weaknesses: the instructor for my sections was not good -- did not offer anything more than just doing the section problems yourself

Strengths: professor, low workload, good material
Weaknesses: large lecture, grades depend mainly on exams

The strengths of this class were definitely within the workload -- it was just the right amount and didn't feel overbearing. Also, professor O'Dea was a very clear and concise teacher, which definitely helped. A weakness of this class is probably the huge amount of people in it, and so sometimes the basics weren't always covered as in depth as some people would have liked it to be.

Strengths: availability of office hours, sections, and instructor
Weaknesses: I was not truly engaged since I realized I did not enjoy econ, but that is my personal experience.

Strengths: as good as a large introductory lecture can get, Cormac's agreeableness and friendly nature, clear course format and organization, communication with students, recorded lectures; Weaknesses: discrepancy between content in lectures and material covered in exams (there's only so much extrapolation / application that students can reasonably do), lack of critique of the overall socioeconomic system that the field of microeconomics functions within

The TF's were so different and the quality of the DS differed drastically (I went to a few different ones). Cormac is a great lecturer. There were many resources for students to use on Canvas which was helpful.
Strengths: Cormac is a great professor; well organized. No weakness.

The biggest weakness of this course is its size, as it is a huge lecture. But there are proportional resources to help students out. The professor, TFs and peer tutors were always readily available to help. The psets did not take too much time to complete and were not terribly difficult. The exams were hard as they were extrapolations of concepts covered in class onto new scenarios, but there were many resources to prepare for them.

Strengths: taught logically, nice pace, wonderful lecturer

Weaknesses: tests, at times, were pretty brutal

Professor O'dea's approach to teaching and also the fact that the lecture was recorded were both strengths. One of the weaknesses is that you didn't really have to engage with econ more than three times a week (lectures and problem sets) unless you wanted which made it easy to forget material.

The lectures are informative and the livestream/recordings are helpful and convenient. The problem sets are an appropriate length, and the optional questions are helpful to reduce the required time commitment but provide opportunity for further understanding. I felt feedback on problem sets could have been more informative and detailed. Discussion sections are beneficial for practice problems, but not so helpful for reviewing material.
I learned more in section than I did during lecture. Problems on exams were not shown before.
I think it was very impersonal teaching style and sometimes, the discussion sections were not interesting.

Strengths: clear format of all lectures, problem sets successfully deepened understanding of lecture content, many study resources provided, helpful TFs and peer tutors
Weaknesses: only complaint was that the second midterm seemed more like a puzzle game than a good evaluation of our understanding

Strength: O'Dea is a great lecturer and does a great job explaining all of the concepts. 
Weakness: not the most engaging concepts, but that is to be expected of an introductory course

This course is highly organized with a very friendly workload. The lecture is recorded and Cormac uploads the slides as prepared and as presented every time. With his notes on them plus the help of the recordings, the slides are extremely helpful for review.
The lectures are really fast.
The teacher was passionate (and funny) which made it easy to engage with the content.

Strengths- online lectures 

Weakness- lectures feel long
It is very well organized. With all the slides and recordings posted after every class.
lectures online were good

I thought one of the strengths of this course was the weekly lectures. I thought they were very clear and insightful. Another strength was all the materials that were provided to the students on Canvas. I found them very helpful when preparing for exams. I can't think of any weaknesses at this time.

I think the primary strength of this class is how well-organized it is. There was never any lack of clarity about when assignments were due and where different documents (problem sets, practice problems, lecture slides, etc.) were located. The lectures themselves were also highly organized, and it was easy to find a particular topic within a lecture when rewatching them. Office hours were also very organized, and it was also easy to log on at a time that was convenient for me. 

I suppose one of the weaknesses of this class, though not really the fault of the class itself, is its size. Due to how large the class was, I felt very anonymous, and it was hard to engage with the material when it felt like no one in particular cared how I was doing in the class. The class requires you to be pretty much teach yourself a fair amount of the material, as there are so many other students in the class that you can't really find any individualized help from TAs or peer tutors. I think another weakness of the class was the sections. I think the section problems themselves were helpful to use when studying for exams, but my TA never really furthered my learning in the section, and most people viewed sections as being optional and thus would just skip, so it felt like a waste of time all around.

The professor is a very skilled lecturer and can deliver course content in a way that is concise and engaging. The weekly sections aid in understanding the week's material and tackling the problem sets. I found no particular weakness in the course.

The problem sets are definitely a strength of the course because they test exactly what was learned in class. The only thing that would be helpful is if there were more examples similar to the problem set done in class.
The class was very good at going through important information and identifying applications, but the problem sets could have been more in-depth.

Sections were not the most helpful. Basically just practice problems, not answering any questions of reviewing lecture material. Also there was not a ton of engagement with the lectures. The pollEV was definitely a strength because it made students apply what we were learning, but many times it was learning things and basically just writing it down without comprehension. Also a lot of the terms would be abbreviated rather quickly, so instead of saying the full term and learning what each curve was etc, I could get lost just because I didnt know what a certain abbreviation stood for. Also many times I was very confident in my answers, and believed they were correct on midterms etc (even sometimes seemingly the same as the answer rubric) but would be marked wrong with no explanation, and even after regrade requests were still marked wrong without ever knowing the reason.

Strengths were the professor, speed of the class, consistent workload structure, access to recorded lecture materials, access to teaching fellows, and open lines of communication between the teaching staff and students. The only weakness was feedback- although there were many opportunities to meet with TF's, their feedback often seemed aimed at helping you obtain the right answer versus understanding how to get there.

Strengths: Professor O'Dea was an engaging lecturer who focused on integrating the concepts into the real world, the course covered important foundational concepts, and the P-Sets were not too time-consuming but still had challenging elements. 
Weaknesses: the class is really big so getting individual attention can be hard

I think the biggest weakness of this course was that half the class had taken an economics class before where as the other half had not. I think this made the class unfair, especially because of the way the curve works. While it was a good introductory course it was fast paced and some students were able to keep up because they had previous exposure to the material. A strength of this class was that classes were recorded.

It is very clear and organized. Hoerver, it is much too mathematical and not very social, which drives many people away from the study of economics. It also moves too fast and covers too many topics at once

I was in a lot of emotional distress taking this course. Not having a strong background in math or any background in economics, I had a hard time applying math to this class which lead to a lot of difficulties. That being said, I understood a lot of concepts in this course which gave me a broader view of the world, and the curve in the class gave me a lot of flexibility to make mistakes.
The material could be pretty dry but I felt Cormac taught it in the most engaging way possible.

Strengths: Super organized, lots of info, very flexible for self guided learning outside of class.
Weakness: Nothing in particular.

Strengths: A good intro class, well paced.

Weaknesses: The class is huge. It can be difficult to get individualized help.
This course is very organized. They have many resources for students and many office hours. It is a larger class, but every student still gets a positive experience and proper instruction.
I liked the lectures, especially when we used Poll Everywhere. The peer tutor office hours were helpful but the TA office hours weren't very helpful. Professor O'Dea is a good instructor.

The lectures were long and conducted in the same manner each time. I think it would be more beneficial to meet more, decrease the class time because there is much information crammed into just two days per week (excl. section), and switch up the format of class every now and then. However, if a student was unable to make a lecture or wanted to circle back to a specific lecture, it was nice that they were easily accessible online and presented in an understandable format.

I also wish I could have been prepared better for the two midterms and final exam. I felt like these were much harder each time than I thought they were going to be.

Strengths: I was so impressed with the curriculum and teaching of this course. The problem sets were short but effective; the lectures were engaging despite the huge class size; the slides were helpful both during and before/after lecture; the Zoom recordings were well made; the exams were challenging but fair; the discussion sections added to the class. Honestly, I loved pretty much every aspect of the class.
Weaknesses: pretty much none! Sometimes the outside office hours were cold.
Strengths: Amazing professor, class was very organized, lots of support. Weakness: Huge lecture environment can sometimes be difficult to learn in

Strengths: very well-structured with lectures, sections, tutor office hours, and additional resources provided. Real life applications were integrated in lecture, and emphasis on building economic intuition were very helpful

This course was well-taught and the material was often tied to real life scenarios. There were interesting tangents during lectures about current research in economics and the applications of this type of work. 

The sections and review sessions werent always super helpful in clarifying the material because Professor ODea sometimes taught things differently than the TAs.
Strengths: Cormacs a great lecturer. Weaknesses: section really varied based on who your TF was.

strengths: amazing teacher, good lecture format, interesting material
weakness: need more practice problems

Lectures are quite engaging, and the Professor does a good job of tying the material to real world examples. The second midterm felt a bit too hard, while the first midterm felt a bit too easy, such that it is unclear what level of understanding is expected of us.
The problem sets are helpful in consolidating the knowledge. The PowerPoint slides were very helpful.

Strengths: professor lectures very well, problem sets are pretty easy, provides strong economic foundation
Weaknesses/Areas to improve: Sections were not that helpful, review sessions were also inconsistent in quality
This course was well taught. Overall I wouldn't change anything.
Very well organized, lots of resources, accessible P Sets.
The organization on canvas and having the lectures recorded and slides posted helped a lot. I didnt find the section useful though.
The course was pretty fast paced but the content was very interesting. The review sessions for most teachers could be a bit more structured.

One strength of this class is the coverage of material. One weakness was that the office hours with TAs/TFs were not very helpful and the sections are very hit or miss depending on your TA. I learned nothing from my section and very few people ever showed up.
The pace of the course seemed to be uneven

The course provides a broad and important introduction to economics as a whole. It is an excellent introductory course for someone who has not had any prior exposure to economics. However, the following course is extremely large, and it can be hard to keep up for those who are not used to extremely large lecture formats.
I think this course can be improved by improving the sections.

The strengths of this class are that its well taught and covers a lot of materials. However, in such a large class it can be hard to focus. To improve the class I would suggest doing more examples of the work in class.
i think that the discussion sections were the weakness of the course and instructors often made the information more confusing rather than clarifying
Despite the large nature of the class I thought the problem sets helped to solidify the information learned in lectures.
I really enjoyed this course

Strengths: very clear lectures, lots of office hours support, sections were helpful

Weaknesses: Truly, not many. My only complaint perhaps would be that sometimes the problem sets were a little too abstract. In a perfect world, problem sets are extremely application-based rather than theoretical graphs.
Lectures very good.

Strengths: online recordings to wtach at a later date. 
Weaknesses: the TAs and section structure.

The lecture is very helpful. Cormac is a very good teacher, and he makes sure to make is class entertaining and engaging. The TAs and sections, however, were not very helpful. It really depends on which section you are placed into, but mine was a complete waste of time. On the bright side, though, the course provides you with more than enough practice materials for exams, and the workload is minimal.
Fantastic, engaging and passionate Professor. Course was incredibly well organised and the material was interesting and very enjoyable.

Strengths: Good material that is useful in the real world 
Weaknesses: Not a very engaging class which i think is caused by such a big class (not really my style of learning).

The course is very flexible for a course with 500 students. I'd say that section could be run a bit smoother because a lot of the sections felt unproductive. It would have been helpful to receive some feedback on problem sets and midterms as well when they were returned to us. Other than that, everything was great!
Strengths were the number of topics that we covered but we did not go into that much detail in any of them. Also we were given very general advice on how to solve problems.

strengths: lots of extra help
weaknesses: fast pace
Prof. Odea was a wonderful teacher. TAs were hit or miss.

I think that one area in need of improvement is the experience at section. To be honest, I rarely got anything out of section and had to do the problems on my own. This was partly due to the fact that my section leaders did not explain the problems in an intuitive way, and sometimes were hard to understand because they did not speak english well. I think that a better experience in section would have allowed me to understand the course material significantly faster.
I think its a good large lecture course. The sections worked well with the large lecture style.

I actually really liked the pace of this courseit didn't go too fast or too slow. The problem sets were engaging and helped me improve my understanding of certain topics. Professor O'Dea was a great lecturer, always prepared to answer questions, and provided online access to those who were unable to attend for whatever reason. The exams were challenging but not unreasonable; if you paid attention in class and in discussion sections, you could definitely manage them. There weren't any major weaknesses to this course, although it might have been nice to see a stronger connection between lectures and discussion sections.
Strengths: Professor O'Dea, the lectures, exam study resources, peer tutors. Weaknesses: sections, feedback, review sessions.

Strengths: fantastic lecturer, clear expectations, reasonable workload 
Weaknesses: discussion sections are a toss-up (some good some bad), slightly hurried at times, limited feedback

The course provided me with a great basis for microeconomics and I can confidently say that I learned more in this class than I did in any of my other ones. The strengths were that the lectures were live recorded, the slides were provided beforehand, and the professor was completely clear.

Prof. ODea did a great job of engaging such a large lecture. He was the strength. Lectures were also well-organized, and the recordings helped when studying. The course material does escalate pretty quickly, and if we didnt have the lectures to rewatch, it wouldve been quite difficult to keep up. Sections and TFs were very hit-or-miss.
More cohesive lesson plans from TAs - preparing for discussion sections with friends outside my own section became difficult as plans diverged.

Strengths: Cormac O'Dea, availability of office hours and peer tutors, simplicity of directions, predictability of weekly schedule
Weaknesses: Large class can make you feel insignificant, difficult to participate, section effectiveness varies
Better TAs

It was very helpful to have lectures recorded the ability to pause and rewatch enhanced my understanding of course material. Additionally, office hours were useful when I needed help on problem sets. Furthermore, Cormac O'Dea is an incredible professor and is particularly fit for such a large course. His poise and elegance for maintaining focus and attention with hundreds of students was crucial.

Strengths - Professor O'Dea was without a doubt the biggest strength this course had to offer. His lecture style was easy to follow, clear, and covered the topics very well, and he was an absolute joy to listen to. Dr. Morar as my section leader was also a great strength, as she was extremely knowledgeable, clear, and concise in her explanations of relevant course content. The course was very well-organized, which also helped to expedite studying, as well as problem sets. The problem sets accurately covered the exam content. Finally, the option to take the course asynchronously was a big help in terms of study efficiency and scheduling. 

Weaknesses - There isn't much to cover here, but the fact that the grades are curved is something I've never quite understood. We also didn't receive feedback on problem sets, so when I got some back with points taken off for "minor errors", I couldn't use them as a study reference to help prevent future errors from occurring. Finally, the course is a very large lecture, so it is difficult to get individual questions answered, other than in section. Professor O'Dea did a great job trying to answer every question in lecture, though.
Class size is very large and pace of learning very fast, hard to get help when falling behind, even section moved at a fast pace

Strengths: well-taught, numerous practice materials. 

Weaknesses: 500 person lectures suck, there's no way around it. There's very little opportunity to engage with the material in a group setting (discussion sections were pretty useless), the class is graded on a curve which promotes individualism, etc.
It got a little boring just because of the lack of engagement.
Its very very large, which is both a strength and a weakness. Theres so many resources available for help in the class, but I also tended to feel slightly more engaged in my seminar classes.
It can be easy to disengage yourself from the content of the course. The content itself is delivered wonderfully by the professor.

I thought this course was organized beautifully. O'dea is an amazing lecturer, so the larger lectures were engaging and easy to follow. The recordings are very well done too if you need to use them. There is a lot of support for students through teaching fellows and peer tutors, so despite the large size of the class, you can get all the help you need. The only weakness I can think of is that the lectures occasionally felt unsafe in terms of COVID-19. We were told to wear masks, but many students disregarded this rule completely and would come to lecture visibly ill.
Very organized

Strengths: thorough, mostly engaging

Weaknesses: large lecture course, difficult

I thought it was fantastic. Organizationally, there were ample resources available to help in a large lecture setting, from abundant practice materials, to review sessions, to frequent office hours and accessible instructors/TF's. Lectures were coherent, and even if I struggled with the content, the lecture recordings and office hours helped me synthesize the materials I needed to. From a student-support perspective, I found it exceptional. 

Discussion sections, though, didn't feel particularly useful. I didn't gain much by attending discussion sections, and oftentimes, when we asked questions, they seemed deflected or half-answered, or otherwise, the TF wouldn't know. Pre-exam review sessions were also hit-or-miss: some were particularly useful, while others were monotonous because they didn't have a plan or covered content that wasn't of concern. I am glad that review sessions occurred because they helped me contextualize and understand examinable content.

One thing that was both a strength and weakness was that lectures were recorded. Because they were recorded I was able to go back and rewatch the lectures in which certain concepts were taught in order to strengthen my understanding of the topic, but also when I fell behind, I got into a bad habit of just relying on the recorded lectures instead of going to class.

I appreciated how little requirements there were for the course, I thought that the weekly problem set was enough. However, it led to me being out of touch with the class because often there was little I could do, and I often forgot to study, reiew, or engage with the content
Professor ODea was an excellent teacher for this course. I think the course could be improved by being less exam-focused.
Professor Cormac made the course incredibly interesting.
Make grading standards less rigid. Emphasize understanding of material and course content not simple mentions of buzzwords / matching the rubric.
The math and more explanation regarding the theory of concepts. It was very difficult to follow these more complicated ideas such as Monopsony

Strength: The lectures were well mapped out and organised.
Weakness: Some subtleties could have been explained better, lectures could have gone through more problem examples.
Great course
Great lectures - very glad that they were recorded. Recordings facilitated my studying a lot.

I liked the weekly p-sets because they were a good way to make sure you never fell too far behind in the course. A weakness was that even if they took points off on the problem set they wouldn't say why so you received no feedback on them.
Lecture format didnt provide good teChing
Cormac is amazing! Best lecturer possible for such a class. The class size is bug but the slides, lecture recording and peer tutoring made it absolutely doable to learn well

Strengths: Extremely well-organized, lectures were clear, topics well-explained, textbook and problem sets allowed for additional practice and resources, & Professor ODea was an engaging, clear lecturer

I really enjoyed how content was available online, including lectures, past exams, and problem sets. This meant that I could engage more with the content of the class and ensure that I learnt the course effectively.
I love the large lecture setting and the weekly sections. I think the problem sets were excellent practice for the exams

There were a few concepts that I didn't fully grasp after lecture, but discussion section and officer hours were extremely helpful ways to fill in any gaps in my knowledge. I was impressed by how the content was prepared in lecture and then reinforced in section, but I know that many people were not too satisfied with their section. I saw why when it came time for the review sessions before exams, and some of the TFs appeared unprepared.

Strengths- the many formats in which the material can be seen (in-person lectures, recorded lectures, live-stream); the emphasis that the course has on economic intuition as opposed to memorization of the material

Weaknesses- some of the TFs explain material in different, contradictory ways to how we learned the material in the main lecture

Strengths: Cormac O'Dea was a GREAT professor. His slides were very clear (good organizational structure for each lecture) and he explained concepts well. The review at the beginning of each lecture of what we had done in the past was super helpful to synthesize and recap knowledge. Also, I liked when he drew out graphs and explained them as he went. The Canvas page was very well organized and Prof. O'Dea was prompt with putting up lecture slides and review material. The optional Pset questions were also helpful because I could go back and do them before exams, but not be worried about perfecting them for submission that week. 

Weaknesses: There was a lot of memorization for the exams (and they could be difficult, but the class is curved). Also, it was a very large course, as is the nature of ECON 115. I didn't go to the in-person lectures at all, but watching the video recordings of the lectures was just as good (and in some cases, even better so I could pause the lecture and take a break). But because of that, it was easy to fall behind in the lectures.
I thogijt the way the course was taught was confusing. Not many practice examples were done in class.
nope
Sections should not be mandatory

Strengths: Lectures were very engaging and helpful. Peer tutors were an amazing resource. Problem sets helped to challenge students. Weaknesses: Getting a good teaching fellow for this class was a luck of the draw. I had a horrible teaching fellow for the first part of the semester, and by the end of the semester only 1-2 students ended up showing up because of how bad they were. They need to prepare all teaching fellows with the same skills and knowledge necessary to properly teach.
I think that I didn't find myself engaged with the subject matter a lot, and maybe more interactive study methods in section would have helped with that.

I think that the course was very good for the most part. I thought that the lectures were very good, the peer tutors were helpful, and the sections were sometimes helpful. I think that the lectures were run just about as well as they could have been. I appreciated that they were recorded, too, which helped with study/review. Whenever I had a question, usually felt like I could resolve the issue by attending office hours. However, sections were not always as useful. Though we were given practice problems during section, it was difficult to have my specific questions answered or concepts explained.

Biggest strength is in the psets, they do a great job at moving through the content and giving fair questions that walk through the week's lectures. Made it feel very manageable, especially with the drop any two psets. They were a huge aid in studying for the exams.
despite the course being very large, there were many resources available to help students succeed
I think it could be improved by doing more examples is class or going over the tough test question from the last problem set at the beginning of class.
Many concepts were not fully explained and presentation was not the clearest.
I liked the lectures and the tutors were helpful. I do think some of the practice exam had content we didnt learn in class and it would have been nice to have more practice problems.
I really enjoyed the material. I feel sometimes the course was over complicated on topics that have simple explanations
It can be improved with more practice problems and bettering the sessions.
S: Teacher was easy to follow and very good at accepting feedback and understanding.
Strengths: many resources to offer help when needed. Weaknesses: is a lecture course so harder to stay engaged

The courses strengths are the quality of the instruction, the engaging was of the class. A weakness (potentially unavoidable), is the class size makes it difficult to completely engage with the main instructor. However, that is also a facet of it being such a large class.
Moved through the material very fast.
The TFs should be more aligned with the course material. Often, what we learned in class was not taught the same way in section, and the TFs did not seem to know what we learned in class.
Big lecture class; in terms of accessing resources, it was good. I did however feel lost from time to time

The strengths of this course are that the professor explains things very well, the lectures are zoom recorded, and my section leader is amazing. The only weakness is that there aren't a whole lot of other ways to be evaluated for a grade outside of the two tests and doing the weekly problem set.
Great course overall.
Strengths are that the slides are very helpful and the TFs are helpful. The weakness is that the class is so big it is easy to not pay attention.

Strength- solid workload
Weakness- sections seem pointless

Stengths: professor Odea is very engaging and makes the information feel relevant

weekensses: sections suck

As the course is a very large lecture, the weekly sections play a very important role in implementing the theoretical skills into algebraic or numerical examples. The textbook could be better incorporated into the course and additional practice problems posted for every lecture, so that you dont easily run out of exercises.
I think the slides that summarized a lecture quickly at the end (one slide per topic) would be beneficial.
TA program is good. Could have better explanations of certain concepts that with more practical examples.

Strengths: Professor ODea is an excellent teacher. Lectures are clear and informative, and psets helped me build an understanding of the material.

Weaknesses: It was unclear what role the textbook served in the course. The lecture slides and additional materials were more than sufficient for learning the course material. Perhaps it would be helpful to treat the textbook as optional reading material instead of required course material.

Strengths: Clear expectations, consistent and predictable workload, recorded lectures, and many resources to turn to for help (e.g. sections, office hours)

Weaknesses: N/A

Strengths: moves at a manageable pace, there were reviews at the beginning of every lecture because it kept building throughout the course, manageable workload and relevant topics (never felt like the material was unnecessary)

Weaknesses: Discussion sections were not helpful or greatly varied by the assigned teacher, no feedback was easily accessible likely just due to the large class size
Evaluation types of units were easier for me, some conceptual things were more challenging.
Great professor, but it was hard to tell how one was doing at any point in the course because of the curve, and no updates on grades.

Some strengths were in having the lectures online, as well as having optional problems on the problem sets so thst u could review more material I was confused with. Some weaknesses were in the teaching fellows who often times did not speak English very well (in my experience) and would therefore confuse themselves in the process of explaining Econ as well confuse me and my peers. This was extremely frustrating, as I would go to office hours, and often leave more confused than I started. So, I think there needs to be more attention in the selection process of TFs.

Lectures are recorded which was useful for midterm/final preparation. PPTs are also available on canvas, which help you to prepare in advance for lectures. Although the discussion sections were great for individual attention, the large size of the lecture hall (~500 students) sometimes made it hard to concentrate.

Strengths: The slides were an excellent resource, tons of support was offered to those who sought it out (so many office hours, review sessions, practice tests, etc.), Cormac has a gift for explaining concepts in simple ways, Psets reinforced concepts from class without being too strenuous, the recordings were very high-quality, class was super organized (really appreciated the short outline offered at the beginning of every lecture), I liked the inclusion of economic research into class when it was appropriate. 

Weaknesses: TFs are very hit-or-miss. Also, I know online finals put the teaching staff in a very hard spot but there didnt seem to be super robust protections against cheating on the final. Forcing students to take the test in lockdown browser and to put their phones on camera in Zoom mightve helped. I worry about the curve on the final being distorted.

The strength of the class was most definitely the professor, Professor Cormac O'Dea, who organized the lectures in such a way that it was fun to learn the material and provided a wide array of real-life examples of the material of each lecture before each class. There was also a great amount of resources available to all students. A weakness was the structure of discussion sections, and I would stress that it really does matter who your TA is and attendance is very helpful!

The courses content was presented in a logical manner - starting with very general notions common to microeconomics and macroeconomics before a deeper dive into consumer/producer theory and then a discussion about market failures. I really appreciated the courses lack of bias towards a particular economic system and Cormacs acknowledgment of the benefits and shortcomings of many common ones. However, I feel that the pacing was not entirely ideal. Certain topics - particularly those in the last few weeks - felt a bit rushed compared to those at the beginning of the year, which perhaps required less thorough explanations.
Very well taught course. Content was straightforward and cohesive. The large lecture setting made it so that your level of engagement was 100% determined by the individual though.
Great professor, only problem is that the clas is really big
There is very little engagement with the teaching fellows and it is detrimental to the education of the students.
more tutoring hours not during athletic practice times

-Strengths: the professor
-Weaknesses: the size of the class

I had a great experience! My one suggestion is, even once pandemic restrictions expire, to continue recording lectures for later review. The amount of material covered in this course is daunting, and my note-taking improved dramatically once I availed of myself of the option to pause and catch up when I needed to. I would've been fine either way, but it was certainly nice, and I encourage you to consider conserving the option.
The professor was very good at teaching concepts clearly, but the pace of the course requires a lot of outside preparation as well.
Strengths include how well-organized it is. Weaknesses include the breath of material we need to cover over the short period.
I really liked the lectures. Section could be improved.
Lectures were fun
