My TF wasn't particularly engaging, so the class often felt very impersonal. The lectures were of high quality and the tests felt fair, though. I really liked the recorded lectures.

strengths: lectures thorough, discussion section questions helpful
weaknesses: some gaps in knowledge not clarified

Strengths - definitely the course format. I think many people really benefited from the discussion sections especially and working through those problems personally helped a lot with revision. Also how well lectures were recorded - when I unfortunately missed one or two lectures during the semester, I found that my notes were as good if not better after watching recordings of those lectures because all the slides were posted, annotated etc. (which wasn't the case with any of my other courses). Especially for a large class, I really appreciated that.

Weaknesses - can't really think of any. I wholly enjoyed the course, perhaps a little more focus on the mathematical aspects would have been nice (for example, I feel like a lot of the questions in review sections were because of us not grasping the maths side of the topics but I understand that with the pacing already structured so well, adding an emphasis such as this might be difficult.
Strengths: Recorded lectures, real life examples used to illustrate abstract topics, plenty of office hours

Strengths - great professor, great lecture slides, it was very helpful that the course lectures were recorded so revising for the exam was very easy
Weaknesses- sometimes the material tested on the exams felt like it wasn't covered in the lectures. Midterm 2 especially seemed out of the course's scope
Strengths: very good teacher, engaging lectures, easy to understand, contents clearly explained, interesting topics
Couldve gone slower

The class was very well organized, and I felt very supported even though it was a large intro class. I appreciated the sheer number of office hours and review sessions, and I found that Professor O'Dea, Dr. Morar and all of the TAs were very approachable.
The lectures are long and fast-paced, but the material isn't too hard to study on your own and develop a better understanding of the material.

Strengths: Organised and consistent schedule structure. Sometimes excellent teaching assistants; sometimes not always the greatest help. Lectures are enjoyable and very well taught. Workload is not unnecessarily heavy or over-the-top. Weekly discussion sections are particularly helpful for the final exam. 

Weaknesses: Past exams not easy to find, and often not enough are provided before tests for practice - especially when tests are very particular. Sometimes office hours for teaching assistants are not the most helpful or well-explained - it might be easier to have a source to send questions to before meeting them.

Strengths - love that there is a lecture and discussion section, that is incredibly helpful
Weaknesses - discussion sections should be longer so we can actually cover all of the information we are setting to cover
Very strong class with good in-person lectures. Problem sets are helpful and good for exams.
I don't think there is much wrong with this class. It was an ideal lecture class.

I would hope to see more engaging lectures, more explanations of how the following material connects back to the material already learnt rather than simply reading from the slides. Yet, I believe Professor O'Dea did an excellent job with this course and I am very thankful for such a great introduction to Economics!

Strengths: all material is in the lectures and the lectures are recorded and posted online, along with practice problems and old exams, knowledge is very relevant to real world. Weaknesses: the material is kind of dry. Personally, I found the material difficult and somewhat boring, but highly important to understand. I fell asleep in class frequently. The format is the same from lecture to lecture, which can limit engagement. In the beginning of the semester, there were few worked examples in lecture, but Cormac took student feedback and improved this over the semester. Oftentimes, the material felt too fast-paced for me to ask a question. Very little feedback is provided on problemsets, so it's hard to know exactly how you need to improve. I would've liked to see clearer problemset feedback.
Professor is great and clearly cares about the students but the class is a little impersonal because of how big it is

Strengths - Professor ODea is highly organized, attentive to detail, and prepared. 

Weaknesses - Limited opportunities for individualized attention, and challenging to cover so much content during lecture.
Very well structured. Lots of resources.

I really loved this course! I think Professor O'Dea was a very engaging lecturer and explained concepts really well. I appreciated how after our midterm course evaluation, he began to incorporate more algebraic examples into our lectures because that helped me understand and tackle the problem sets more efficiently. I also appreciated how many office hours and peer tutors were available to me. Pretty much whenever I was working on a Pset, if I had a question, I could log onto canvas and find a tutoring session that was currently live on zoom at the moment when I needed help. I also really liked having access to previous exams because I found doing old problems was one of the best ways to study. I also really loved the review sessions, those always clarified for me what would be examined, what I needed to study more in-depth, and what topics I felt comfortable with.

Strength: I truly feel like I mastered the material and understand the basics of microeconomics
Weakness: At times the material and lectures could be dull and tedious

Strengths: I felt that there were ample resources students could reach out to for help on problem sets and exam preparation, including numerous TA and Peer Tutor Office Hours. I also liked the online nature of the class, where lectures were recorded and office hours were held online, provided students greater accessibility to learning. 

Weaknesses: I felt that there was a great disparity in the quality of TA's lessons; those with TAs who invested more time into the course benefitted substantially. In addition, I felt that exam material could test not just mathematical understanding but conceptual understanding.

A strength in this course was the many office hours offered throughout the week, which were really helpful in order to ask questions, discuss topics seen in class, and work on problems that were confusing.

Very straightforward about when things were due, where and when exams were, and what was expected from sections. The huge lecture style made it difficult for me to pay attention sometimes, but is necessary with such a large class

Strengths: excellent lectures, problem sets apply course material, exams are reasonably difficult, there are many opportunities for extra help (office hours with the professor, TAs, and peer tutors)
Weaknesses: size of the class, lack of clear feedback on what errors were made on psets and exams

My strengths were participating in lectures and working with my peers on problems sets and exams. My weaknesses were reaching out to the professor and TA's when I needed extra help. For the future, in big lecture classes, I need to be more on top of the task of reaching out, not to my peers, but to the TA's and my professor when I'm struggling with a concept.
The course is very well-designed, and there really were not any issues with the way it was carried out.

The strengths are that it builds a very solid foundation of the course, and there are many office hours to attend if there are any questions. However, because it is such a large lecture, I found it difficult to stay focused during lectures at times, and possibly lowering the capacity could help with that.

Even though I attended almost every lecture in person and when the sections, the single Pset per week caused me to fall behind conceptually since I didn't do much work outside of the course except to finish the PSet. Maybe splitting up the PSet into two parts and assigning them for different days would create a more balanced learning experience.

A great strength was the constant opportunities to practice concepts talked about in lectures. The nature of the class, being so large, is oftentimes tough for students. Connection with professors has helped me with understanding concepts in other courses, and it was tough to create those connections in such a large class, where there was a more social aversion to participating.
I think it is hard to stay engaged overall with such a big lecture setting

I actually think the lecture format worked really well for me for delivering material. It was nice to have clear slides/notes/videos to look back on for each specific thing we learned. A bunch of office hours and tf sections meant there were good ways to get help.

Strengths: pretty engaging lecture, lots of office hours

Weaknesses: in lecture we only learned the concepts and didn't focus on how to apply them, which was supposed to be taught in our sections but wasn't done very well. I found myself understanding the concepts of the course but unable to do the p-sets or exam material, which was frustrating.

Prof. O'Dea was a strength. He is a wonderful professor who will lend a hand and send a quick, detailed email whenever necessary. Weaknesses were that sometimes both problem set and test questions were hard to comprehend.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I enjoyed it, and it was a nice way to get a QR credit.
The economic concepts are interesting but I would recommend skipping right to intermediate microeconomics.
Yes, not too much homework, weekly psets, but very cooperative with students.
Yes! People take this course for so many reasons  I took it because I didn't know any econ and wanted to take a useful class that would use my brain somewhat quantitatively.
Yes; of the two options for introductory microeconomics, this seems like the better choice.
TAKE IT IF CORMAC IS TEACHING IT! He is a fantastic lecturer and clearly cares about his students. This year the course was recorded and posted online which was extremely helpful as well
Yes, to anyone who is interested in economics even the slightest bit! It is a great and interesting intro course

Yes, I think the class is taught well for a lecture, and it teaches skills in quantitative reasoning that are useful for understanding the world. I also think that there is a level of human-ness that is provided by the support of peer tutors, the professor, and the discussion section leaders, that many QR classes don't have, that I appreciate.
I would recommend this course to anyone who 1) wants t gain a basic understanding of the field of economics and 2) wants to try out learning in a large lecture environment.
100 percent yes. Even if you are not interested in an economics major, this class teaches things that are applicable to everyday life.

For students who want a straightforward, comprehensive introduction to economics, this is a great start. An impressive variety of topics are taught and the real-world implications are underlined frequently.
Yes, I would recommend this course to other students at Yale. I think that everyone should have a basic understanding of economics and this course is well-taught.
The material of the class was important and a foundation for the rest of economics, but it was not the most exciting or interesting class.
Yes, this course is a great intro to microeconomics. You will learn a lot and the material is enjoyable.
Yes I would highly recommend this course to another student. I think this course is great for students just wanting an overview of microeconomics.
Yes, it is a very good introduction to economics and a good test to see if it is a field that you might be interested in pursuing.
No.  This course was useless. I was hoping to receive a good introduction into supply and demand, and instead I got a few clumsy explanations.
Yes. Everyone needs Econ in their lives.
Yes
Absolutely! The course gives a great foundation of microeconomics, and it is taught in a well-thought manner that really helps you learn the content instead of emphasizing memorization.
Yes, it is a good course to take in your first couple years, as economics is a field that seeps into many other fields and is very relevant.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because it was fascinating to learn about how firms, individuals, and markets function using graphs and math as well as intuition.

Yeah if you wanna take Econ you have to and it's fine. Also if you're looking for a QR, there are easier ones out there but this isn't too bad and is a nice way to also get the credit and do something that's a prerequisite for lots of other stuff.
Yes, economics is essential to life.
Yes! If you have any interest in economics, this is a great introductory class to see if you might have more interest in the subject in the future.

I would recommend this course, as I think it is a great foundational class to understand economics. My only complaint would be that it felt as if students who had previously taken econ classes were very ahead of other students in terms of understanding the content. For me, everything was new, but for some of my peers, it was mostly a review of content that they had learned in the past.
I would highly recommend. Just a great introductory class. Not too hard, very fun, and teaches a lot of valuable study skills.

Take this class! It will change how you think about the world and make you so much more insightful. Thinking like an economist is an incredible skill that will help you no matter what you pursue. The class is super interesting and very engaging, and the teaching team is incredible. This is an essential class; take it!
Yes. Good QR, not overwhelmingly difficult.
Yes! Great intro econ course and great, non-intimidating QR for a non-STEM student.

I would definitely recommend even if you are not looking to major in economics. It is a useful introduction to the subject and Cormac was a really great professor - honestly pretty entertaining lectures overall. It was a class I always looked forward to and a great way to bond with lots of other first years!

I would definitely recommend this as a starting point for anyone looking to study economics or just to get a taste of what economics is. It is catered to a variety of individuals, meaning that there is not need for a background in the subject area.
Yes
Yes.  This class gives you a basic understanding of how taxes, monopoly etc, works. Even if you are not interested in economics, you will learn something helpful in this class.
Yes, I believe it is a vital course in establishing basic economic concepts.
I would take this course even if it isn't a requirement for your major - it is easily applicable to every other aspect of life.
Yes. I think this is a great way to learn the subject, and I think the course provides all the resources you need to do well.
No
I would if they have a background in economics because if you dont you have to do a lot of outside work.

I would wholeheartedly recommend this class with Prof. O'Dea. His lectures are incredibly good: the explanations are clear, he works through lots of examples, and he's funny and engaging (which can be tough in a class of 500+ students). Put simply, I looked forward to coming to this class each time. Additionally, the workload was very consistent and manageable - problem sets were not incredibly long, and they did a good job of cementing the topics we'd learned in the lectures.
no unless you like economics and math
Yes, but specifically with Professor O'Dea. I believe that if it weren't for his teaching, I would have strongly disliked the class.

Yes. As someone who was interested in pursuing econ as a major it was incredible. If you're not, the combination of it being an interesting subject, fairly simple to learn, and a strong instructor makes it worth it. I would avoid 115 specifically if you don't want a big lecture because it's literally 500 people but I didn't mind that.
Yes.  Professor O'Dea is a great lecturer, the material can be interesting, and the workload isn't too high.
If they have interest in economics, this is a good intro course!
Yes. It's an interesting course that was taught well, and the content is interesting whether or not you want to major in economics.
I would recommend this course to any student as it is an interesting, and real-life applicable course which you do not need prior economics knowledge for.
Yes, if you have to take this course as a prereq, you'll take it anyways. If not, might not take it, just because to grasp a good understanding of econ, this course alone is not enough.
I would only recommend this course to econ majors to be honest because although I definitely learned a lot I also did not enjoy the course content that much to be honest.

If you're interested in economics, this is definitely a very good introduction. I've heard some horror stories about the other professors that teach this class, but Professor O'Dea was one of the best professors I've had thus far at Yale.
Yes, strong introductory economics course
If you are interested in economics then I would recommend but if not no.

I was recommended to take ECON 108 -- but 115 was totally fine. You don't need any background in calc/higher level math to do well in this class. I'm not hugely interested in Econ, but given that, Cormac does a fantastic job. He's a great lecturer and very organized and empathetic to students!
Yes, the professor is great
I would definitely recommend the course to anyone interested in economics or looking for an interesting QR credit. I learned a bunch and it wasn't an incredible amount of work.
Yes, especially if you are interested in basic/intro economics.

Although intro classes are not always the most interesting, I would absolutely recommend this class to students as it teaches fundamental concepts that are very important for life. Economics is one of those classes I think everyone should take at some point in their life.
I would not recommend this course unless you're really interested in economics.
Yes. Very well organized.
Yes! Whether you are econ major or not, this is a great course that will help you think differently about the world and make you realize how much economics truly infiltrates your everyday life.
Yes, if they are interested in economics and are thinking about pursuing this major.
Why not, it is an introductory course.
Absolutely. The curve is awesome and psets are easy and graded super easily (plus you can literally drop the two lowest). I found the lecture to be super fun and I absolutely loved Cormac.

I took this course as a major requirement, as was the case with many other students. It's not too bad as an introductory lecture course, especially because nearly a third of the first-year class seems to be taking it. I did learn a lot of technical skills and microeconomic course content in the class (as this was my first ever econ class). It wasn't a transcendent learning experience, but it did provide a lot of context as to how the economy functions as I continue to critique and question systems of power and wealth.
Yes. Though maybe only if Cormac is teaching it.
Yes if you are interested in the world or economics or how people make decisions.

Yes. Its an interesting introduction to economic concepts. If you are a STEM major and need to get a social science requirement, this course actually involves a lot of math (though it is pretty simple).
If they're interested in learning the basics of microeconomics, it's an essential. Try to take the class during a year when Professor O'dea is teaching.
Definitely. With no prior experience in economics, I found this course manageable and the material very understandable.

Yes, even though it's just a requirement for many majors/tracks, it was taught very well. It's challenging enough to be interesting, but not get totally lost. If you're looking for a QR credit, though, I think there are easier ones.
Yes, but only if necessary. You will not learn anything riveting in this class.

I would definitely recommend this course to anyone whos even remotely interested in (or even suspicious about!) econ. I didnt like econ at all before I took it and Im not sure I do now. But Im glad I took it as this course really taught me new ways to look at the world, which I think everyone should at least be open to learn about.
I would if you need econ courses
Yes! The teacher was amazing, and the content was interesting.
Only if its required for their major
Yes! Learned a lot about the actual material as well as study/learning methods.
yes
I would recommend this course to another student looking to gain a basic understanding of economics. It's very well taught and will be very useful, especially for prospective economics majors.

I think if you are simply looking for an easy QR class, this is not the course for you; it is not easy and requires a fair amount of effort to be successful in the class. However, I think the concepts the class teaches are ones that everyone should at least have some understanding of as an informed citizen of the world. So, yes, I do recommend this class, but students should not expect it to be a walk in the park even if they are strong at math.

I would highly recommend this course to any Yale student. In fact, I view it as an essential course that all undergraduates should take irrespective of major. The course gives a foundational understanding of economics that will be helpful in understanding real life consumer theory.
Yes! Cormac is a great lecturer and this is a good introduction to microeconomics. There's plenty of opportunities for extra help if you need it.
Yes, it is a great introduction course especially since it is a large lecture. The content of the course is also very basic and fundamental knowledge which is beneficial to everyone.
No, doing ECON is just not worth it because it is horribly dull and you will either want to credit D Fail or drop it if you don't really care for it..
Yes, I would recommend because the fundamental skills of economics are taught in this course, and in an engaging manner.
I think it is necessary as an intro course, but there were many parts of the course that really frustrated me (especially with grading and mistakes in PowerPoints or grading rubrics).
Yes, because it is a great foundational course to have. No, because econ as a subject is terrible :)

Yes, if you need a QR and/or need the class for a prerequisite. I'm not sure if I'd recommend it for students purely interested in studying economics for an intellectual challenge, and might recommend the smaller seminar (Econ 110) instead, but I don't have experience with that class so I can't say for sure. Professor O'Dea put a lot of effort into making the big lectures as interpersonal and interesting as possible, which I appreciate.
I would. It is a good introductory course to the economics faculty at yale and it shows some clear concepts that one would study if one pursues the major.

Yes! This course, at least when taught by Prof. O'Dea, is great for students who aren't big on STEM to learn about how the world works through an econ lens. The curve makes it hard to get less than a B+, so I would definitely recommend as a QR and just a good way to gain econ literacy.

If you are curious about economics, especially microecon, then definitely. Otherwise, the material will probably be pretty boring. Cormac teaches at a reasonable pace and does his best to show real-world applications of what we learn
Yes, so long as they like being in a huge lecture. Its a good intro class and isnt too difficult.
Yes.

Yes, if you like econ or think you might like it. The psets don't take too long to do (2-3 hours/week if you do both the required and optional questions). Professor O'Dea is a good teacher and explains things clearly.
If he/she needs it for his/her major then yes, but I did not particularly enjoy this course.
Yes, absolutely. I think this course teaches skills that every educated citizen/voter should have, and it was done very well.
Definitely! The course was organized very well, and the professor was amazing! You will learn a lot about the basics of economics with this course.
Most definitely. Even if you aren't an econ major, it teaches you a way of analyzing problems.
Yes

Yes, if youre looking for an introduction to the field of econ. Professor ODea is a great professor. I think its great to have a foundation in this area, but also make sure youre doing your own thinking about how the models you look at in class can play out in real life.
Yes! Great introductory course to micro.
Yes this class was great and engaging. You dont even need to be an econ major to emit this course, you meant a lot about how society works.
Yes
I would recommend taking this course if you need to take micro for a major or if you just want a strong introduction to economics.
This class is a great foundation for further economics at Yale College. I certainly would recommend it.
I would recommend the course to another student if the student would like to gain a very basic understanding of microeconomics.
Yes - it allows you to understand microeconomics very well and provides a strong foundation for moving to other economics courses
Yes
Yes. Everyone should take some econ. This course won't blow your mind, but it's a very solid, comprehensive intro into an important topic.
Yes. Micro is essential to start thinking like an economist, a rather useful way of viewing the world.
Yes, it provides a great introduction to economics.
Yes, only if they plan to major in Econ or take more Econ classes. It is definitely not a gut or a course just to take for the QR credityou must be somewhat interested in the material.
yeah i would, it it good to get an introduction to economics
Yes, it isnt much work, and the material is very interesting.

Yes. Despite having no prior introduction to economics and as someone who does not intend to be an economics major, the skills that were taught in the following course were extremely important and truly changed my worldview and conceptual understanding of fundamental economics. It teaches important fundamental skills that are extremely applicable to real-world settings. I would highly recommend this course to anyone.
yes I would, odea was an amazing professor
Yes, I would it is a great introduction to Microeconomics.
If someone is looking to get a taste of economics to see if it interests them, I would recommend this class.
yes. beneficial as introduction to economic concepts
I would as this was a good way to learn introductory microeconomics.
Yes.
Yes. It is essential for thinking economically and it was wonderfully taught.
I would not recommend it as an easy QR req, which was what I was looking for in this class.
Yes if you want to learn more about the decision-making process in a mathematical way. No if you are looking for an easy A as a QR.

Yes, particularly with Professor ODea! The lectures were always fun, the exams were fair and there were so many great resources on offer to help aid improvement from peer tutors to Professor office hours.
As a baseline for economics, yes. If you are wanting to be an Econ major I highly recommend it but if not I wouldnt say it is super necessary to take.
This course requires a lot of self-teaching, with the right initiative anyone can handle it, but it will require work.

I would recommend this course to those who have an interest in the subject. It's not an easy QR code, but if you are interested in majors that use or require these skills, obviously you should take the class, and it's not a bad class.
I would recommend this course even if they are only slightly interested, because this is valuable knowledge to have.
yes, if you are thinking of declaring your major in economics
Yes. I think the material was very useful and the professor was great.
Yes, I think this is a good course if you are interested in economics.

I would recommend this course to other students, especially if they are considering economics as their major. It is a great introduction to microeconomics and it will help you see what you're going to get yourself into.
If you are interested in microeconomics absolutely. Professor O'Dea is an amazing teacher and the class is superbly well run and with abundant resources.
Certainly, as a major requirement or just if youre interested.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in economics and learning more about markets.
I think everyone should take intro micro, regardless of your interests or intended major.

Yes- the course serves as a good foundation in economics at yale, and I feel it prepared me for  the possibility of taking other economics courses. Professor ODea is very knowledgeable and made the lecture as engaging and informational as possible given the size of the course.

I would recommend this course because I think it is a great introduction to microeconomics, which is exactly what is promises. If the name sounds promising, it's definitely worth taking. That being said, someone who's not interested in economics should not take this class. It can be very dull if you don't like the general subject.
Yes, because it can be used for a lot of things.
Absolutely, especially with Cormac O'Dea as the professor. It is a foundational course regardless of your major and will provide key frameworks for understanding the world we live in.

Absolutely, especially if your major is pertinent to economics. Professor O'Dea made the course enjoyable and easy to follow, and the course content was interesting and quite painless, especially for a QR credit. Microecon is a great course to take if you're looking to better understand the world around you, as well.
Yes
If you want a basic foundation in econ/need it as a prereq, sure. Because of the curve, I think you can save yourself a lot of headache by taking it credit/d or auditing it.
I would, especially because the knowledge gained applies to many things outside of the class and in the real world.
Yes. It is a good into to econ. The professor is also a very good lecturer.

I would highly recommend this course. It is a great way to get an easy QR credit, and it was the course that made me want to be an economics major. You learn a lot (particularly with O'dea), and the workload is very easy to handle. All the problem sets were graded based on completion and only took about an hour or two each. The tests were a little difficult, but the curve is very generous. Overall, it was one of my favorite classes this semester.
yes because it is a good entry level course
I would only recommend to someone who needs to take it.

Yes, very much so. Partly because it's a prerequisite and a solid foundation for several social science majors, but also because it develops a mode of thinking that I find useful as a consumer and a member of society. The course provides insight into foundational structures and interactions that occur in economies, so I'd recommend it to anyone interested in a social science-adjacent discipline or for an interesting class at all.

Yes I would recommend this course because it was interesting to be a part of an experience shared by so many members of my first year class. it also is a good introduction to economics and I'm sure it inspired many people to want to pursue the subject and also helped people realize that it was not something they wanted to further pursue.
Yes
If youre looking for an easy QR, look elsewhere, but if you want to learn something useful and somewhat challenging, this course is a good fit.
If its with Professor ODea, absolutely. Otherwise, it depends whether you think a basic economic intuition would be useful for you.
Grading is somewhat unpredictable especially in the second midterm. Only take the course if you need it for a major.
No I would not simply because it was extremely difficult for me to get through and hard for me to focus on since I wasnt as interested in the subject matter.
Yes, if its required.
Yes
Yes. Great to have a basic understanding of economics no matter what major you are in.

Eh it was a good course if you're interested in econ, but I wouldn't say it was life changing. Very mediocre in most ways. The lectures are super large so it's easy to fall behind and stop going or just not pay attention. Some sections/teaching fellows are good and some aren't. To be honest, I wasnt crazy about ECON 115 for the first few weeks of the course. It felt like a compilation of oversimplified and unreasonably generalized models with little applicability. But as the course went on, I began drawing more and more parallels between the theory we studied and the dynamics of real-world economies, and Cormacs incorporation of empirics certainly helped this point. By the end of the semester, ECON 115 was one of my favorite courses, as it helped me develop a new way of thinking that is useful in both academic and everyday life. For these reasons, yes, I would recommend this course to other students.
If you like are wondering whether or not to major in econ, yes.

I encourage anybody and everybody to take this course. I'm not a math person, and I wasn't expecting to like economics very much, but enrolled in Econ 115 anyway because I thought that building a basic understanding of firm behavior and market dynamics was an important part of being an educated citizen. I got that and more. The material is difficult but genuinely interesting and relevant -- I'm shocked how much the frameworks I learned in this course have already shaped the way I process the news I read and the world I see around me. I also found that it was very possible to succeed and do very well given an appropriate amount of effort, and that the coursework is truly intelligible without any particular background in or aptitude for economics. 

If you have the chance, take this class with Cormac O'Dea. He is a very clear presenter and obviously cares for the wellbeing of his students. I credit my good experience to him.

Yes! Prof O'Dea was an incredibly lecturer who clearly enjoyed teaching and made lectures as engaging as possible for a 500+ class. There are an insane amount of resources (discussion sections, TFs, peer tutors, years of practice midterms and finals, etc), lectures are very well organized and easy to follow, the workload is very reasonable (weekly psets, two midterms, one final), and the curve is VERY generous. I would recommend this course for students who are required to take it for the Econ major or need a QR requirement, as economics underpins almost every area of study. I would warn students that taking high school economics won't necessarily provide you a leg up in the course, and encourage students who've never taken economics that it's a fairly level playing field; much of the material covered after the first four lectures confronts advanced economics topics incorporating algebra and critical thinking.
